reviewText:
I've put a ton of hours in on Tower! 2011, and I'd suggest to wait on a purchase.

Missing many features of Tower! 2011:

- No voice command.
- Unable to select trafic density.
- Only one setting for time compression.  You either play real time, or max acceleration.  No 2x, 4x, etc.
- Extended commands (i.e. VIA" and "AFTER TAKEOFF FLY...") are not part of the UI
date: have to be typed manually.\n- You cannot type two commands in at once (You have to type "TAXI TO.."
voteText: select the aircraft again and then type "AFTER TAKEOFF FLY.."
helpfulPercent: hit enter).\n- Graphics issues (landing lighs are spheres of illumination the radius of a 737 cockpit).\n- UI issues (limited zoom
votesTotal: no way to change the size of text on the strip window).\n- Planes readback is not in common avionic parlance (250 is read "two fifty" instead of "two five zero").\n- Limited setup options (can't turn off bloom
commentsCount:
etc).
- No manual or charts.

Feels like a beta more than a finished sim.  Hope they will fix the issues."

reviewText:
Please read this all text for an understanding of why I recommended this game despite its current deficiencies.  This is based on a very short stint (the tutorial, plus a few minutes outside of the tutorial).  So with that qualification:

While the premise is promising and there is definitely potential, the game has a very unfinished feel to it.  The very first tutorial aircraft I encountered pushed back from the the St. Thomas terminal like a proper airliner... wow, neat.... except for the fact that it was a Cessna.  OK then.  Then on the GA ramp that typically would have hosted the Cessna, a Dash 8 type turboprop taxiied right though the farm of its fellow turboprops to get to the taxiway.  The game took a slight hit to suspension of disbelief there.  And the Cessna thing seemed pretty darned obvious to me.

Rushed.  But could be fixed.

Pros: Promising mechanics, aircraft behave more or less as they should when commanded.
Cons: Rudimentary graphics and textures.  Aircraft movement is not terribly smooth.  View control is poor; zoom functionality is not terribly effective.

This has the potential to be a really good and engaging sim, but it's not there yet.

My advice - buy it to support the developer and encourage them to keep working on it.  Try it out.  You'll probably be disappointed.  But come back in 6 months and I expect (or hope) that it will be signficantly improved from its launch state.
voteText: 19 of 25 people (76%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What is it?
Tower 3D is an Air Traffic Controller game aimed towards the casual end of the 'simulator' genre of games.  It's no ATC2 or Global ATC (and doesn't pretend to be), but it's not a lightweight time management game like Airport Madness either.  Tower 3D is aiming for a very neglected middle ground for ATC sims, so I had huge hopes for this one!

However, given that Tower 3D is really the only middle ground title that's both globally available and current, I'm disappointed at the missed potential here.  It didn't need to do anything different (all the basics for an excellent casual game are right there) but it should have done them all so much better!  Anyway, here's a list of the good and bad stuff so you can decide for yourself:


What's to like?It's a fun presentation of ATC (ie more than maps and a radar screen) for people new to the genre
A basic tutorial mode is provided
While casual, it's not too dumbed down
Aircraft strips have plenty of details about speed, direction, attitude and altitude
There is flexibility to type specific commands as well as click pre-defined instructions
The game offers 3D views of planes taking off and landing
It's an ATC game that doesn't require an Einstein-esque level of knowledge in Geometery and Physics!

What's not to like?The graphics are actually horrible - so much so that I suspect this must be a serious bug (aliasing, flat and muddy textures not at all like the video presentation, little shading, low resolution aircraft with blurred decals) - definitely NOT 'stunning' as described!
There are no free-camera options whatsoever - you can only zoom in slightly and have no control over the direction of view, and the camera frequently gets stuck pointing at nothing until the next plane arrives which can take a while
It's missing some basics such as 'holding short' of the runway, expediting aircraft, accounting for wind factor and such
Only the ground controller role is simulated (there's no tower, approach or departure gameplay)
All commands are read by the same female voice - there are no 'radio' voice recordings and no variety
The UI leaves a lot to be desired with windows that are difficult to resize or reposition for a better fit, and various buttons in dire need of basic tooltip descriptions
Gameplay is somewhat slow-paced and I soon became bored
If the poor graphics and limited audio are not faults, then it's too expensive for the level of quality provided (it's more of a £7 game rather than £22).
No manual to explain more detailed options
It feels very 'Early Access' yet is actually a fully complete title.

Should you buy it?
If this was an Early Access game, I'd say 'yes' to support the developer and help the game develop into a polished product, but it's not EA at all so there has to be the assumption that no further improvements beyond patches will happen.  As a result, I don't recommend it - especially not at this price point.  However, remember that Steam does have a 14-day window in which to return games provided you've not played them for more than 2 hours so you could always try it out if you're unsure.  People who have never played an ATC game before will probably find it fun, but anyone who has played a semi-casual game like ATC3 will just notice how much poorer it is compared to other games in this niche.

If the game should improve (ie the terrible graphics and frozen camera do turn out to be bugs), I'll revisit this review.  I'm not refunding it because I know Dovetail does maintain Train Simulator very frequently, so I'm keeping hope.  Right now though, it's really not a good game to spend a lot of money on, and I'm really sad about that.


Some alternatives to look for:
Casual
Airport Madness!  (stupidly fun, casual time-management game)

Intermediate
ATC3* (pitched at the same level as Tower 3D)

Serious
ATC2 (vintage, but still current and the most serious ATC to date)
Global ATC ('new kid on the block' but has a free playable demo you can try)

______________

* ATC3: I Am An Air Traffic Controller (its full title) can only be bought as a full product from Technobrain (in Japanese only).  A very expensive offshoot Tokyo Big Wing" was released internationally with just ONE of the 12 airports and only about 10 minutes worth of game (so it didn't sell too well).  However
recommended: fans of the original full product (with all 12 airports and related missions) have made English-translated versions for download from various sites around the world. Note that ATC3 is in no way similar to the much more serious ATC2."

reviewText:
As a complete noob on atc games I enjoy the game so far, but expect more out of it in updates. Its not finished and should have been a beta. Its much too pricy in its current form.

Things I expect in the future for starters:
-Talk, both from my commands and from the pilots. Voice command is not a mandatory req. for me, but the choice to use it would have been cool. Talk should be by voice actors and not computerized, it sounds awful.
-Choice of different cameras, better zoom on the camera and a free roaming camera.
-More airports and planes to choose from.
-A game manual. Tips and tricks for newbies.
-Maps over the runways and more choices in commands.

Overall, the game potential, and I really have high hopes on the developers as they have done a firly good job with the predecessor games in 2d as I understand it.

reviewText:
Simpler but worst.

- Cannot ask for aircraft to hold short of runways.
- Graphics are very poor, probably using Google Earth for ground textures
- Ground, taxiways and runways are not aligned, so sometimes aircrafts taxi out of the airport zone (KLAX 25R) or are parked on taxiways...
- Commands are way too simple, basically are ''clear to taxi'' ''clear for takeoff'' and ''clear to land'' only.
- Very not user-friendly
- Lack of settings is incredible
- No text to understand the voice of pilots
- That mentionned voice of pilots is always the same male text-to-speech dude, feels like a robot.
- You will end up with penalties and you will never know what you did wrong, they will just remove points from your score.
- Sound effects are very low and not varied.
- Aircraft textures are very very very low.
- Not what you see on the screenshots and on the video.

Refunded after 45 minutes.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is the only game in the entirety of my time on Steam that I have chosen to go to the efforts of getting a refund for. Considering how much development was made throughout Tower 2011, you would have thought those developments would be the bare minimum in the new release...unfortunately not the case. I became instantly irritated at the game after the absolutely atrocious lack of control in regards to audio. The music is infuriating, and there was no way to turn it off without muting the entire game. The tutorial was lacklustre, and provided no real insight into the operations of ATC for anybody new to the aviation world. There were numerous bugs, including aircraft landing on a runway and somehow colliding with aircraft that were on the parallel taxiway, which were en-route to the holding point ready for departure. The whole feel of the game is just wrong. The heavily advertised 3D" element to the new release is rather boring too. Aircraft pushing back through scenery
recommended: and a seemingly random way of switching views that the user has absolutely zero control over.\n\nFor the price
hoursPlayed: this game is absolutely disgusting. I highly suggest spending your money on something complete
voteText: this is not even close to completion."
